I like the policy overall.  Very minor commentary having read it, but overall, I like it.
I'm going to steal this description in the future......  It's a really good intro.
In the docs repo do we generally do out of line links?  We're probably not consistent.... not sure it matters.
There were multiple examples and so I needed multiple links. Not sure that there's a tidier way to represent it except for picking arbitrary words in the sentence to link?
Done
Should this go in the commit message as background, rather than in the doc itself?  It keeps this doc self-contained, while still tracking the history in the commit.
This was meant to be a bit of a conclusion to tie together the two sections that had been discussed so far.
Fine as-is if you want to keep it.  Changing this is unimportant to the greater goal.

I like the sentiment overall, but one thing I would note about OpenBMC is that a lot of actions ARE irreversible, or aren't reversible without herculean effort: libpldm, having to fork the webui because of early design decisions, bmcweb legacy rest mode that we still have to keep, because folks still use it, and we have no way to measure usage across the project.  Security vulnerabilities add another avenue to this, because they essentially CAN'T be a two way door.  The minute a SEVERE vulnerability is injected, the project is at risk.

"action" takes a lot of forms, and IMO, "merge to master" isn't the action we need to talk about.  I've seen "bias for action" used to justify drops in quality and maintainability, because "action" is required, and I think the bias for action framework alone misses a lot of the other leadership principles that keep it in check.

That's all fair.

However, rather than applying it blindly I used it to cause me to pose the question "Is this reversible?" to each of the considerations below. So it wasn't so much a philosophy as a prompt.

I could probably have explained that better in the text though.

> That's all fair.
> 
> However, rather than applying it blindly I used it to cause me to pose the question "Is this reversible?" to each of the considerations below. So it wasn't so much a philosophy as a prompt.

Sure, I guess that's fair.

> 
> I could probably have explained that better in the text though.

ACK
Done
Or a lizard;  We're still not sure.  Lizards still have limits though.  😄
nit, caps.
Ack
Actually, that's a semi-colon, not a colon, so no capital required :)
TIL

As a side note, when I talk to those that have forked the project, this stability problem overall is top of mind for reasons why they did it.  Some folks call it "repeatability" in that version to version the stability isn't great.  Not sure if this doc can do anything about that, just reinforcing the sentiment.

Right. I think that's a useful complaint to send to the list; I'm not sure it has a role in this document because it's a problem we have even with active maintainers. But maybe this was a subconscious driver for your merge window suggestion :)

> Right. I think that's a useful complaint to send to the list; I'm not sure it has a role in this document because it's a problem we have even with active maintainers. But maybe this was a subconscious driver for your merge window suggestion :)

ACK.

Is this a real concern or something we've seen in practice?  Sure, the phosphor-rest maintainers probably don't know anything about bmcweb, but that's why they're separate.  I wonder if this paragraph should be removed, and treated as a more ad-hoc thing.  In my experience, maintainers coming back and their knowledge being out of date hasn't been a significant problem, but of course, that's opinion.

> Is this a real concern or something we've seen in practice? 

Hopefully the following paragraph helps answer:
Yeah, that's a good point.  ACK.
One minor typo. Otherwise, it looks great!

I don't have any particular problem with this and would be OK with accepting it, though it does go into substantially more breadth & depth on background, various parties' motivations, etc. than I had been expecting.  I don't really disagree with any of it (and it's not entirely irrelevant), but I would also be fine with a few paragraphs or so summarizing approximately the last two sections.

Okay. So speaking with at least Brad he said he liked having the rationale in the document. One thing I've coonsidered is flipping it on its head and putting the process up front and having the rationale follow it. That way people who just care about the process have it immediately available, but for those that care about it, the rationale is still there.

That said, the breadth and depth exists because the proposed process didn't emerge in a vacuum. The proposed process exists because I wrote down the background and thought about the impacts.
No serious concerns from me.

> One thing I've coonsidered is flipping it on its head and putting the process up front and having the rationale follow it.

That sounds like a decent idea to me, FWIW.

nit: this is really hard to read in markdown.  Maybe a () list?

Is `[bookmark][]` really valid syntax?  FWIW, this doesn't talk about it: https://www.markdownguide.org/basic-syntax/#reference-style-links

> nit: this is really hard to read in markdown.  Maybe a () list?

Let me experiment to see if I can make this more readable. But concretely, what do you mean by a () list? Can you provide an example?

> what did you mean by...

This looks slightly easier on my eyes to me:

    [[1][]][[2][]] -> ([1][],[2][])
Ack

This wording struck me as a bit odd; personally I don't generally think of FOSS as an "open-source aware practice" so much as a...philosophy?  Methodology?  (Not sure exactly what term to use.)  I'd certainly agree with fostering good FOSS/open-source practices, though I'll admit I don't have any great concise examples I'd cite off the top of my head instead...
This is a quote from the the maintainer workflow document, so I guess discussion here should actually be a patch for that.
Ah, missed that it was a quote.  In that case should we leave it as just a reference instead of duplicating text, so that if we do change it we only have to do so in one place?
I felt it was worth quoting for the impact and avoiding the need to break the flow while reading.
A while back I added these points to the maintainer workflow to give some guidance for how to elect a maintainer.  Feel free to improve them.
Done
Wording nit: "contributions of code or code review" would read slightly more naturally IMO.
Again, this should be a patch for the maintainer workflow document.
Done
Ack
nit: typo
Good catch.
Done
Taking style cues from https://xkcd.com/37/ I see...

hahaha, whoops, I brained.

Let me fix that.
Done

Maybe "approximate" as a slightly more explicit nod to the difficulty of pinning down exact numbers and definitions here?  (And leave a bit of wiggle room for interpretation/judgement on behalf of both the potential complainant and the TOF.)
Yeah, there are probably better words. I was trying to indicate that I expected people to challenge them.
I've dropped the hedging and just went for assertive instead :)

Consecutive seems like a really high bar.  That means someone has to disappear for 3 months straight?

Maybe 3 periods of unresponsiveness in a 12 month period?
I've done a call-out on discord to try get the thoughts of others: https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/867820390406422538/1050204475626897418

> Consecutive seems like a really high bar.  That means someone has to disappear for 3 months straight?

Agreed...

> Maybe 3 periods of unresponsiveness in a 12 month period?

...but waiting a year before taking action seems like awfully high latency IMO.

Which of course just further emphasizes the challenges of precisely defining this.  I'd honestly be sort of inclined to make it much more nebulous, maybe something like "if a subproject's maintainers have been consistently unresponsive or excessively slow to respond for a period of at least ~3-6 months".  The openness to interpretation of course leaves us potentially vulnerable to people being overly aggressive in petitioning the TOF, but my (optimistic, perhaps naively so) inclination would be to let people use their judgement -- if a particular individual becomes an excessively frequent complainant we can ask them to dial it back.  If we get flooded with complaints we can perhaps revisit the policy to raise the threshold for lodging one, but to hazard a guess I'd expect that complaints will likely remain infrequent enough that it wouldn't be problematic for the TOF to address them case by case, even if they don't all result in any actual maintainership changes.

>> Maybe 3 periods of unresponsiveness in a 12 month period?
> ...but waiting a year before taking action seems like awfully high latency IMO.

I didn't mean we would have to wait a year.  3 consecutive months would also satisfy the requirement immediately (... since it is 3 of the most recent months in the last 12).

I don't care what the numbers are here.  I've experienced the behavior of a maintainer disappearing, finally getting their attention, and then they disappear again.  If all they have to say is "see, I showed up once" it kind of defeats the purpose of this whole process.

I thought we'd discussed before something like:
- period of inactivity results in a "warning".
- some number of "warnings" results in us finding a new maintainer to add.

That's what I'm trying to make sure we're either covering as we want to, or being explicit that that's now how we're trying to operate.

Ah, alright...

I guess the risk of a precise definition is that cases that *should* merit consideration of maintainership changes could hit some exception in our definition, and someone negatively affected by the unresponsiveness doesn't escalate because it doesn't meet the requirements we've laid out in the rules.  So I suppose it's a matter of weighing that risk against the risk of people being too quick to escalate.

Personally I think I'd still lean toward a "vague and flexible" definition over a rigidly-defined one (we'll know if we hit the bad case because the signal is obvious, whereas it's harder to notice if people are silently having real trouble and not escalating).

I'd like to let the conversation here continue while I push another patch to clean up the other stylistic comments, i.e. I won't change the wording of this section until we get some consensus on how specific or vague we want to be (reading the commentary so far makes me think of hysteresis, but I also think that's over-specifying things :) )

Feels like something that "you know it when you see it" so making it a bit more generic as Zev points to makes sense to me. I do think that with a more vague definition, there should be a specific mention that a majority of TOF members must agree (vote?) to go forward with adding a new maintainer.
I personally prefer clear rules so there is no claim of partiality in the decision making.  I'm fine either way we go though.
In Discord, I suggested the complaintant document a "pattern of unresponsiveness" by giving specific examples as above.

I like the idea of lifting it to "a pattern of unresponsiveness". I think that's vague enough that there's some discretion there, but requires that someone establishes and defends the position that a pattern exists. I think the TOF can establish the existence of a pattern based on a complaint without requiring the complainant do all the legwork. It should be easy enough for the complainant to make a claim about the existence of a pattern which is then established by the TOF as part of validation of the complaint. If the complainant wants to supply all the evidence as well, then that's a bonus (less work for TOF members).

I had some further thoughts here and have done a bit of a u-turn on my comment above:

I think intermittent responsiveness might fall outside the scope of the proposal. If maintainers are responsive enough not to fall afoul of the proposed cap of 3 consecutive months then really it's a matter of discussing onboarding others with them when they are responsive. If they're not engaging in that discussion in good faith that's when we may need to take further action. I think if maintainers are not engaging in the project in good faith it calls into question their continued presence in the community, which is a problem with broader scope than just their role as maintainer. Such behaviour is actively detrimental rather than just an inability to meet the community's need for progress.

The proposed 3 month cap is a bound to define it cannot be argued that you're not unresponsive as a maintainer, and justifies community action to mitigate it without further input as a means to avoid deadlock. In that context, taking action when people are even only intermittently responsive starts to feel like overreach.

My concern is that the current proposal as written is too weak that it doesn't solve the original issue.  I do understand that we should be communicating with the maintainers that the community doesn't feel their responsive enough though.  My suggestion would be roughly:

* After 1 month of inactivity anyone may raise a complaint to the TOF, who verifies that there has been a pattern of inactivity.
* TOF reports the verified warning to the maintainer(s) and suggest if they are unable to keep up they may want to seek out assistance (we can probably write a form-letter for this).
* After 3 warnings, and communication attempts by the TOF, in a 12 month period, the TOF takes action to appoint an additional maintainer.

> My suggestion would be roughly:

That's pretty reasonable. I think I felt the emphasis on actively communicating with the maintainers was missing and I didn't unpack that feeling well enough to ask the question about intent. I was thinking in terms of the TOF measuring backwards after the three non-consecutive periods of unresponsiveness, determining the violation and immediately taking steps to on-board a new maintainer. By changing the wording to three warnings rather than three instances of inactivity there's no opportunity to remove maintainers without actively trying to engage them.

I'll leave a bit of time for this to simmer in the comments and then I'll update the wording if there's no significant opposition.

> By changing the wording to three warnings rather than three instances of inactivity there's no opportunity to remove maintainers without actively trying to engage them.

Err, not remove maintainers, but introduce new maintainers without further engagement.

Not enough coffee.
Done
Would this patch being merged imply merely acknowledgement of a proposal, or adoption of a policy?  I had sort of assumed the latter, in which case "Proposed" seems odd.
Yeah, this is my proposal, and I was floating it to get feedback. Given that most commenters so far seem happy with the process I think we can drop "Proposed".
Done
As a thought, could this look better if these were a sub-list of 2?
Let me try that.
Done
Sub-list of 9?
Let me mull that over.
Done
Seems okay to me both as a frustrated contributor and as an unresponsive maintainer.

Should this document mention the following?: At the project level there is no prejudice against unresponsive maintainers.  For example:
1. Someone who lost a maintainership can regain it through the regular process.
2. Is the project happy to have a sporadically responsive maintainer?

> 2. Is the project happy to have a sporadically responsive maintainer?

I don't think so.  If someone isn't willing to be relatively consistently responsive, they shouldn't give the impression that they are a "maintainer".  List yourself as a reviewer so you get informed and can provide feedback when you're able, but don't put yourself up as a block for others to get code merged.

> 1. Someone who lost a maintainership can regain it through the regular process.

Yes, they might be able to eventually but they need to repair the ding to their reputation first.

Bear in mind that the document isn't proposing removing maintainers, only introducing new maintainers.

+1 to Patricks reply.  While there is certainly value in sporadic engagement, having folks with authority, but no required responsibility can lead to deadlock as we've seen in the past, and is the point of this document.  Of course, there are likely arrangements among maintainers that can keep forward progress with overlapping responsibilities if maintainers need to "go dark" for a time, and can hand off responsibilities to others in an orderly fashion, and by my read, this policy doesn't preclude that arrangement, even if it doesn't explicitly call it out.  This doc only applies if someone has made a report that things are not happening an an orderly fashion.
